Title.evidence: Incisional Negative Pressure Wound Therapy in Infrainguinal Vascular Surgery: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either iNPWT or sterile gauze dressings.

Participants.evidence: patients aged over 18 years undergoing elective open infrainguinal vascular surgery.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either iNPWT or sterile gauze dressings.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial evaluated the efficacy of incisional negative pressure wound therapy (iNPWT) compared to standard gauze dressings in preventing surgical site infections (SSIs) and assessing quality of life after infrainguinal vascular surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of SSIs within 30 days, measured using the ASEPSIS scoring protocol.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using an online system with a block size of ten.

Blinding.evidence: surgeons were blinded to the dressing type.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Of 123 patients randomised between 2018 and 2023, 109 completed the study.

Result_Outcome.evidence: SSIs occurred in 15% of the iNPWT group and 25% of the control group (P = 0.340).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events related to the device led to withdrawal in 7 patients.
